byline.contributor: Andrew Jacobs reported from Tianjin, and Javier C. Hernández and Chris Buckley from Hong Kong. Dan Levin contributed reporting from Tianjin, and Keith Bradsher and Michael Forsythe from Hong Kong. Yufan Huang and Adam Wu contributed research from Tianjin, and Mia Li, Vanessa Piao and Kiki Zhao from Beijing.
byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS, JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and CHRIS BUCKLEY

abstract: Rui Hai International Logistics has become symbol of corruption in China in wake of chemical explosion in Tianjin that killed 150 people and left more than 700 wounded; interviews with former associates and clients of Rui Hai, along with Chinese state media accounts, reveal company that exploited political connections to avoid governmental oversight of shipping of hazardous chemicals; explosion has raised questions about cost to public health and safety presented by party officials pursuing development projects.
lead_paragraph: Rui Hai International Logistics, whose warehouses were hit by the deadly explosions, has become a symbol of the high cost of rapid industrialization in a closed political system rife with graft.

headline.main: Behind Deadly Tianjin Blast, Shortcuts and Lax Rules
headline.print_headline: Behind Blast, Shortcuts and Lax Rules

snippet: Rui Hai International Logistics, whose warehouses were hit by the deadly explosions, has become a symbol of the high cost of rapid industrialization in a closed political system rife with graft.
